{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3208002,"name":"Benjamin wybrow","username":"benjamin1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/96bed5/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-05-16T23:32:02.377Z","cooked":"

Why do most teams use CAN over PWM. PWM seams better if it becomes unpluged you only loose one motor over everything after the problem.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-16T23:32:02.377Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":638,"reads":390,"readers_count":389,"score":3298.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"Benjamin wybrow","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59085,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3208005,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-16T23:37:39.721Z","cooked":"

PWM is one-way communication. CAN is 2-way.

If you use CAN, you don‚Äôt need a bazillion sensor wires coming back to the RIO to tell it what the motors are doing.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-16T23:37:39.721Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":389,"readers_count":388,"score":142.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208006,"name":"","username":"EHutson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ehutson/{size}/177423_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-16T23:38:27.168Z","cooked":"

You can also have a lot more devices on CAN than pwm

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-16T23:38:27.168Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":386,"readers_count":385,"score":152.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"","primary_group_name":"FUN","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51376,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FUN"},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/3","custom_user_title":"FUN","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208008,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-16T23:39:51.517Z","cooked":"

CAN generally allows you to use ‚Äúsmart‚Äù motor controller features, including:

  • Built-in PID loops run directly on the motor controller, allowing for precise position and velociy control
  • Current limiting
  • Easier use of encoders and limit switches attached to the motor controller

Furthermore, CAN has a higher ceiling of devices (there‚Äôs probably a way to get more but by default the RIO only has like 10 PWM slots, vs. up to over 100 for CAN), and allows you to configure encoders, limit switches, etc. directly from the MC, while simplifying wiring as everything goes back to the MC itself rather than a ton of ports on the RIO.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-16T23:39:51.517Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":180.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/4","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208044,"name":"wgorgen","username":"wgorgen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wgorgen/{size}/10106_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-17T01:24:54.501Z","cooked":"

I think there is a place for both. Using swerve as an example, we use direct Analog inputs into the RIO to initialize the module position and then use the motor encoder for control from that point on, so we do not rely on that analog input for control. The motor controllers are connected via CAN. But generally, the motor controllers can be located in a protected location on the robot where those wires are not at risk of damage. For our arm this year, we did something similar where we used the REV through-bore encoder for initialization and then the motor encoders for control.

CAN is very powerful, but does represent a single point failure, so it needs to be protected. Analog sensors can be used to sense the position of a mechanism, but if the wires are exposed to potential damage, it us best to not rely on those wires for mission critical functions.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-17T01:25:39.579Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":158.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"wgorgen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32535,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208611,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T18:40:37.584Z","cooked":"

To add to what others have said, another issue we‚Äôve found with PWM is it‚Äôs much more vulnerable to electromagnetic interference than CAN is. Last season I worked with a team whose robot (which exclusively used PWM for motors) would not run at all, in spite of all the wiring looking fine (or at least, plugged in correctly), we put some Ferrite cores on the PWM wires to suppress any potential EMI and it immediately started working again. The EMI from all the motors was actually enough to prevent the robot from running at all.

CAN networks can introduce single points of failure, particularly in daisy chained configurations. My team has gotten around this by using a ‚ÄúBus‚Äù configuration instead of daisy-chaining devices and it‚Äôs worked very well for us for the past few years (albeit, there are some limitations to doing this).

Another benefit of CAN is that with all the CAN sensors available now (not just the motors themselves), having a CAN network means you can easily connect sensors to the network since sensors are often located very close to motors, thus reducing the number of wires you need to run back to the RoboRIO. CAN makes electrical much easier and cleaner, when done correctly.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T18:44:05.780Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":84.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrite_bead","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Ferrite bead - Wikipedia","clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208615,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T19:02:01.145Z","cooked":"

What everyone else said.

Also, PWM connection to the RIO and many motor controllers is through Dupont connectors. They‚Äôre pretty decent inside a computer or other device that doesn‚Äôt move around very much. An FRC robot, not so much.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T19:02:01.145Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":51.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/7","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208657,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:10:59.531Z","cooked":"

Also, CAN allows ‚Äúfollow me‚Äù where one motor controller slaves itself to a different controller. That‚Äôs very useful when you‚Äôre running a gearbox with multiple motors or putting motors at opposite ends of a shooter shaft.

That said, PWM lets you control a motor from a very simple device without having to write ANY software. Very useful in prototyping.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:10:59.531Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":155,"readers_count":154,"score":71.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50684,"username":"crueter","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208659,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:14:18.803Z","cooked":"
CEF:

That said, PWM lets you control a motor from a very simple device without having to write ANY software. Very useful in prototyping.

PWM‚Äôs simplicity is unmatched. I‚Äôve been pushing for us to use PWM on simple, encoderless actuators such as an intake or simple singulator due to how much simpler it is to wire (plus, it‚Äôs one less failure point for CAN), but unfortunately I have been unsuccessful.

Although in small prototypes, CAN is generally almost as simple as PWM (either way, it‚Äôs a connection or two and a PD* connection).

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:14:18.803Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":151,"readers_count":150,"score":45.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/9","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208660,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:15:11.349Z","cooked":"

Technically you can do this over PWM through software too, but it‚Äôs definitely simpler to implement with CAN (probably less code overhead too). EDIT: bobbysq had an even better solution below

I will agree with you on your last point though. We used to be able to use those little Thrifty Throttle devices to run PWM controllers for testing and prototypes which was way more convenient than the ordeal you have to go through to get any CAN motor to work (especially getting around the RIOs heartbeat restrictions).

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:15:54.557Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":138,"readers_count":137,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/thrifty-throttle-3","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Thrifty Throttle 3 - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208661,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:15:13.264Z","cooked":"

PWM also allows follower mode with no software changes needed:

image670√ó670 33.8 KB

cbale2000:

I will agree with you on your last point though. We used to be able to use those little Thrifty Throttle devices to run PWM controllers for testing and prototypes which was way more convenient than the ordeal you have to go through to get any CAN motor to work (especially getting around the RIOs heartbeat restrictions).

As far as I know, every legal CAN motor controller also supports PWM, hence why Victor SPXes and Falcons ship with Dupont connectors on their CAN leads. You won‚Äôt have any sensor feedback, control loops, or most importantly for brushless, current limiting though.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:20:03.943Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":121.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/2/2/220edd295fea1d1ab7a488270a68b2f3ba3e2d96.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/11","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208662,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:22:55.053Z","cooked":"

Ok. PWM doesn‚Äôt do reverse follower mode, where one motor turns clockwise and the other turns counterclockwise.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:22:55.053Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":44.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28014,"username":"bobbysq","name":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208663,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:24:01.142Z","cooked":"
bobbysq:

As far as I know, every legal CAN motor controller also supports PWM, hence why Victor SPXes and Falcons ship with Dupont connectors on their CAN leads. You won‚Äôt have any sensor feedback, control loops, or most importantly for brushless, current limiting though.

Don‚Äôt you have to put them into like a ‚ÄúPWM Mode‚Äù in the case of the SparkMax and Falcon though? I was under the impression it was not a simple as just connecting a PWM wire. In the case of the SparkMax in particular you have to replace the actual connector on the controller with the PWM one too.

Plus, aside from that, I have to assume a fair number of teams running CAN aren‚Äôt using the stock Dupont connectors due to the obvious reliability issues with those connections.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-05-18T20:25:37.602Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":39.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":437190,"topic_slug":"pwm-or-can","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pwm-or-can/437190/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3208664,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-18T20:25:31.253Z","cooked":"

Sure does.

You just gotta wire the motor backwards on one of the speed controllers. This doesn‚Äôt work on brushless motors, though.

cbale2000:

Don‚Äôt you have to put them into like a ‚ÄúPWM Mode‚Äù in the case of the SparkMax and Falcon though?

As far as I know, you don‚Äôt have to do that, but I think the only time I‚Äôve personally used PWM with a CAN motor controller was with a Talon SRX. The Spark MAX documentation indicates it auto-detects.

cbale2000:

I have to assume a fair number of teams running CAN aren‚Äôt using the stock Dupont connectors due to the obvious reliability issues with those connections.

I hope so. The clips they give you seem to help but there‚Äôs just far better options out there between lever nuts, various JST connectors, and the Molex connector next year‚Äôs KoP will supposedly come with the crimper for.
